newsitem.title: ROMANIA: RADIO ROMANIA NEWS HEADLINES AT 4 PM.
newsitem.headline: RADIO ROMANIA NEWS HEADLINES AT 4 PM.

text.p: * Workers at the Brasov-based state-run truck manufacturer Roman SA are demonstrating in the city centre to protest over bad management and planned restructuring of the company.
They demanded that a government team be sent to Brasov.

* The leader of the major trade unions federation Cartel Alfa threatened to stage protests starting April 17 if the government does not promote vital reform laws, including measure to protect employees in companies affected by job cuts.
* Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea met a delegation of the International Monetary Fund led by the IMF's chief negotiator for Romania, Poul Thomsen.
The IMF team assessed restructuring and privatisation steps taken by the government in line with pledges under a loan accord expected to be debated by the Fund on April 23.
* The government's fiscal, budgetary and monetary measures taken so far have given the expected results and have had positive effects on the markets, Thomsen said.
He said he trusted inflation would drop in the coming weeks, once reform measures were consistently applied.
* Thomsen hailed the stabilisation of the leu exchange rate to the dollar and the functioning of the foreign exchange market.

* The government will file to the Fund a letter of intent signed by Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea and a memorandum on the government's planned reform measures. The documents will be analysed by the IMF board meeting on April 23.
* There is no negative report on the stage of reforms in Romania, Poul Thomsen told journalists.
* The lower Chamber of Deputies rejected an amendment to postpone an April 30 deadline for the country's five private ownership funds to turn into investment companies.

* Opposition Party of Social Democracy spokesman Teodor Melescanu told a news conference his party had evidence of negotiations between ruling coalition partners on appointing the managers of the country's state banks and public utilities.
Melescanu said this was an intolerable mixture of politics into Romania's economy and called for President Emil Constantinescu to intervene.
